title: Ncurses spack build appears to not yield `ncursesw6-config` OR Htop has a bug
body:
As the name suggests, ~I'm not 100% sure if this is a bug in `spack` or `htop` but~(see EDIT) in both the **develop** and **v0.10.0** branches, `ncurses` does not use lib-suffixes when compiling version 6.0.   
Version 5.9 seems to not have this issue.

This was discovered while attempting to compile `htop ^ncurses@6.0` via spack and finding that it failed to use the located ncurses headers leading to an `htop` interface lacking in text.
```
configure: WARNING: ncursesw/curses.h: present but cannot be compiled
configure: WARNING: ncursesw/curses.h:     check for missing prerequisite headers?
configure: WARNING: ncursesw/curses.h: see the Autoconf documentation
configure: WARNING: ncursesw/curses.h:     section "Present But Cannot Be Compiled"
configure: WARNING: ncursesw/curses.h: proceeding with the compiler's result
configure: WARNING:     ## ----------------------------------- ##
configure: WARNING:     ## Report this to hisham@gobolinux.org ##
configure: WARNING:     ## ----------------------------------- ##
```

This appears to be due to `htop` looking for `ncurses` with the lib-suffixes, but the default spack install of `ncurses` disables this with `--disable-lib-suffixes`.  Ncurses 5.9 does not have `--disable-lib-suffixes` as an option...at least it looks that way after a quick grep of its INSTALL doc.

From ncurses 6.0 docs:
> --disable-lib-suffixes
> 
> Suppress the “w”, “t” or “tw” suffixes which normally would be added to the library names for the --enable-widec and --with-pthread options.


There is an open issue at https://github.com/hishamhm/htop/issues/573 that seems to be related to what I'm seeing here, so depending on the debate of lib-suffixes V. no lib-suffixes, this may not be something Spack will need to address.

[EDIT] Honestly, after doing more digging on this issue, it *seems* like this is more of an `htop` issue than a `spack` issue...but I figured I'd submit this to get record of this issue.  Hopefully I'm not the only one that can reproduce this issue :expressionless:
